message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The "bag of worms" appearance, lack of transillumination, and pain suggest varicocele. Varicocele is more common on the left side due to the anatomy of the left testicular vein draining into the left renal vein at a right angle, whereas the right testicular vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of an enlarged “bag of worms” in the scrotum and lack of transillumination suggest a diagnosis of varicocele. Varicocele is more common on the left side due to the drainage of the left testicular vein into the left renal vein at a 90-degree angle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, physical exam findings, and lack of transillumination indicate a diagnosis of varicocele. Varicocele is more common on the left due to drainage into the renal vein. Option (B) is therefore the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of an enlarged “bag of worms” upon palpation and lack of transillumination points to a varicocele. Varicoceles are more common on the left side due to drainage into the left renal vein, which has a higher resistance to flow compared to the right renal vein.

Varicocele is more common on the left side due to its drainage into the left renal vein which has higher venous pressure compared to the drainage into the inferior vena cava on the right.

This is in contrast to the right testicular vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava at a more acute angle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The enlarged scrotum and lack of transillumination suggest a varicocele, which is more common on the left side due to the left gonadal vein draining into the left renal vein at a 90-degree angle, creating a higher likelihood of back-up and pooling of blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, an enlarged "bag of worms" upon palpation of the painful scrotal region that does not transilluminate, suggest varicocele. Varicocele is more common on the left side due to the anatomy of the scrotal veins, which drain into the left renal vein at a perpendicular angle, making them more susceptible to reflux and dilation.
